Description: Gold amuletic pendant: this tiny solid cast figure represents Ptah, the creator god of Memphis, patron of craftsmen. Characteristically, he is depicted mumrniforrn with only his hands emerging to grasp a 'was' sceptre with its distinctive slanting animals head. However, he does not wear his usual straight divine beard, and instead of wearing a skull-cap appears to have a shaven head. There is a suspension loop in the small of his back.
Curator's comments: An amulet in this form might be worn in life as a sign of particular devotion to Ptah. For the dead, however, the image of so powerful a deity would afford protection during the fraught passage to the afterlife. Bibliography: 'Egyptian Treasures' [exhibition catalogue] (Shanghai, 1999), 112-113 No 31.
Bibliographic references: Andrews 2000 / Egyptian Treasures from the British Museum (p.94-95)
